DataElement.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Chromogenic in situ Hybridization HER2/neu Copy Number Polymorphism Outcome Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the number of HER2/neu Copy Number Polymorphisms, the variation in the number of copies of the ERBB2 Gene at 17q21.1 encodes ERRB2 Receptor Protein Tyrosine Kinase, a 185 kD type I membrane glycoprotein that controls cell growth with features similar to EGFR, as determined by chromogenic in situ hybridization, a technique that combines the sequence-specific detection aspects of FISH with the simple detection methods of immunohistochemistry.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Chromogenic in situ Hybridization HER2/neu Copy Number Polymorphism Outcome
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to result of chromogenic in situ hybridization, a technique that combines the sequence-specific detection aspects of FISH with the simple detection methods of immunohistochemistry, to detect the variation in the number of copies of the ERBB2 Gene at 17q21.1 encodes ERRB2 Receptor Protein Tyrosine Kinase, a 185 kD type I membrane glycoprotein that controls cell growth with features similar to EGFR.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredName: Chromogenic in situ Hybridization HER2/neu Copy Number Polymorphism Outcome
Property.preferredDefinition: Chromogenic in situ hybridization is a technique that combines the sequence-specific detection aspects of FISH with the simple detection methods of immunohistochemistry. Briefly, sequence-specific probes are hybridized to cells fixed on slides and the sequestered probe is visualized by a peroxidase reaction. It has the advantage of being a less costly assay that does not require fluorescence microscopy with results that are stable over time.:The ERBB2 Gene at 17q21.1 encodes ERRB2 Receptor Protein Tyrosine Kinase, a 185 kD type I membrane glycoprotein that controls cell growth with features similar to EGFR. Ligand binding increases phosphorylation of tyrosine residues. A potential heterodimer with ERBB3 and ERBB4 receptors, p185ERBB2 is an essential component of the heregulin/neuregulin receptor complex. ERBB2 homodimers do not bind heregulin but ERBB2/ERBB3 heterodimers do. Neuregulins do not interact with ERBB2 alone. The IL6 cytokine induces tyrosine phosphorylation of ERBB2 and ERBB3, but not EGFR. ERBB2 forms an IL6-dependent complex with the IL6R gp130 subunit resulting in MAPK activation. Expressed in fetal kidney and liver, herstatin is a 68 kD secreted product of an alternative ERBB2 transcript that retains intron 8. Herstatin binds p185ERBB2 as an inhibitor by disrupting ERBB2 dimers and reducing p185 tyrosine phosphorylation.  (from SWISS-PROT, OMIM and NCI):Variation in the number of copies of a particular sequence within the genetic material of an individual. Large-scale copy number polymorphisms are common and widely distributed in the human genome.:Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

Concepts.definition: A laboratory procedure that combines the sequence-specific detection aspects of FISH with the simple detection methods of immunohistochemistry. Briefly, sequence-specific probes are hybridized to cells fixed on slides and the sequestered probe is visualized by a peroxidase reaction. It has the advantage of being a less costly assay that does not require fluorescence microscopy with results that are stable over time.
This gene plays a role in cellular proliferation and is involved in the oncogenic process through amplification and/or overexpression in several cancers.
Variation in the number of copies of a particular sequence within the genetic material of an individual. Large-scale copy number polymorphisms are common and widely distributed in the human genome.
